com.pump.plaf

Class DecoratedPanelUI

  • java.lang.Object
    • javax.swing.plaf.ComponentUI
      • javax.swing.plaf.PanelUI
        • com.pump.plaf.DecoratedPanelUI

  • public class DecoratedPanelUI
extends javax.swing.plaf.PanelUI
    This PanelUI offers several attributes to provide more modern and sophisticated panels.

    The attributes are broken up into two groups:

    • Border Attributes: these are applied to the border, which can be applied separately as a javax.swing.Border.
    • Panel Attributes: these are applied to the panel as a whole, which means they affect the middle of the panel as well as the border.

    The DecoratedPanelUI.Renderer class manages painting all attributes. Both the DecoratedPanelUI.Border and the DecoratedPanelUI defer to the same Renderer to paint everything. (But both entities clip the Graphics2D destination strategically to only paint the appropriate portions.)

    Here are examples of some of the harder-to-describe attributes. (These samples may not show each feature in the most compelling/flattering presentation, but they should help demonstrate what different attributes do.)

    Glaze:

    		Bevel:

    		Corners:

    Scribble:

    		Shadow:

    See Also:
    DecoratedPanelUIDemo, Panels: an Improved UI

      This is used by both the DecoratedPanelUI.Border and the DecoratedPanelUI to render all the attributes.

      • GLAZE_LEVEL

        public static final ObservableProperties.Key<java.lang.Float> GLAZE_LEVEL
        The attribute defining how tall make the glaze, ranging from 0 to 1.

      • GLAZE_OPACITY

        public static final ObservableProperties.Key<java.lang.Float> GLAZE_OPACITY
        The attribute defining how opaque make the glaze, ranging from 0 to 1.

      • COLOR_TOP

        public static final ObservableProperties.Key<java.awt.Color> COLOR_TOP
        The attribute defining the top color of the vertical gradient. If this is null, then only the COLOR_BOTTOM is used. If that is also null, then the panel background is used. (And if that is null or panel.isOpaque() is false, then the body is left empty.

      • COLOR_BOTTOM

        public static final ObservableProperties.Key<java.awt.Color> COLOR_BOTTOM
        The attribute defining the bottom color of the vertical gradient. If this is null, then only the COLOR_TOP is used. If that is also null, then the panel background is used. (And if that is null or panel.isOpaque() is false, then the body is left empty.

        public DecoratedPanelUI.Border getBorder()

      • paint

        public void paint(java.awt.Graphics g,
                  javax.swing.JComponent c)
        This paints the UI.

        This method relies on the DecoratedPanelUI.Renderer class to paint everything, but first it clips the Graphics2D to hide the border (so the border will render separately).

        Overrides:
        paint in class javax.swing.plaf.ComponentUI

      • blendColors

        public static java.awt.Color blendColors(java.awt.Color a,
                                         java.awt.Color b,
                                         float p)
        Blends 2 colors together
        Parameters:
        a - the first color
        b - the second color
        p - the progress (as a decimal between zero and one) to use. When p is zero, the color returned is "a". When p is one, the color returned is "b". When p is .5, the color is 50% "a" and 50% "b", etc.
        Returns:
        a color that is between a and b.
